correct_answer: ![A graph that starts in the top left, drops steeply down as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply up back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical U shape.]()
wrong_answer: ![A graph showing a curve that starts in the bottom left, moves steeply up and right, levels off briefly, then continues steeply up and right.]()

text: recognise a quadratic graph from its shape which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph? ![a graph with two curves. one curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. it starts at the top close to the y axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x axis. the other curve is in the negative x, negative y quadrant. it starts at the top left close to the x axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the y axis then becomes almost vertical to travel almost parallel to the y axis. ]()
question: Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph?

text: use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \) below is her working out. what conclusion should eliza draw? \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \) \( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term
question:
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
construct_name: Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not
